009
010package imagingbook.lib.math.eigen;
011
012import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
013import static imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix.createDoubleVector;
014
015/**
016 * Implements an efficient, closed form algorithm for calculating the real 
017 * eigenvalues (&lambda;) and eigenvectors (x) of a 2x2 matrix M of the form
018 * <pre>
019 *   | a b |
020 *   | c d | </pre>
021 * There are typically (but not in general) two pairs of real-valued 
022 * solutions 
023 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>1</sub>&rang;,
024 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>&rang;
025 * such that A&middot;x<sub>k</sub> = &lambda;<sub>k</sub>&middot;x<sub>k</sub>.
026 * The resulting eigensystems are ordered such that
027 * |&lambda;<sub>1</sub> &ge; |&lambda;<sub>2</sub>|.
028 * Eigenvectors are not normalized, i.e., no unit vectors
029 * (any scalar multiple of an Eigenvector is an Eigenvector too).
030 * Non-real eigenvalues are not handled.
031 * Clients should call method {@link #isReal} to check if the resulting eigenvalues
032 * are real or not.
033 * <p>
034 * This implementation is inspired by Blinn, Jim: "Jim Blinn's Corner: 
035 * Notation, Notation, Notation", Morgan Kaufmann (2002) -
036 * Ch. 5 ("Consider the Lowly 2x2 Matrix").
037 * Note that Blinn uses the notation 
038 * x&middot;A = &lambda;&middot;x for the matrix-vector product (common computer graphics),
039 * while this implementation adopts the notation 
040 * A&middot;x = &lambda;&middot;x.
041 * Thus matrix A is transposed (elements b/c are exchanged).
042 * </p>
043 * This implementation is considerably (ca. factor 5) faster than the general solution
044 * in {@link EigensolverNxN} (based on Apache Commons Math) for 2x2 matrices.
045 * 
046 * @author W. Burger
047 * @version 2021-05-19
048 */
049public class Eigensolver2x2 implements RealEigensolver { // to check: http://www.akiti.ca/Eig2Solv.html
050        private final boolean isReal;
051        private final double[] eVals = {Double.NaN, Double.NaN};
052        private final double[][] eVecs = new double[2][];
053        
054        /**
055         * Constructor, takes a 2x2 matrix.
056         * @param A a 2x2 matrix
057         */
058        public Eigensolver2x2(double[][] A) {
059                this(A[0][0], A[0][1], A[1][0], A[1][1]);
060                if (Matrix.getNumberOfRows(A) != 2 || Matrix.getNumberOfColumns(A) != 2) {
061                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix not of size 2x2");
062                }
063        }
064        
065        /**
066         * Constructor, takes the individual elements of a 2x2 matrix A:
067         * <pre>
068         *   | a b |
069         *   | c d | </pre>
070         * @param a matrix element A[0,0]
071         * @param b matrix element A[0,1]
072         * @param c matrix element A[1,0]
073         * @param d matrix element A[1,1]
074         */
075        public Eigensolver2x2(double a, double b, double c, double d) {
076                isReal = solve(a, b, c, d);
077        }
078        
079        @Override
080        public int getSize() {
081                return 2;
082        }
083        
084        private boolean solve(final double a, final double b, final double c, final double d) {
085                final double r = (a + d) / 2;
086                final double s = (a - d) / 2;
087                final double rho = s * s + b * c;
088                
089                if (rho < 0) {  
090                        return false;           // no real-valued eigenvalues
091                }
092                
093                final double t = Math.sqrt(rho);
094                final double lambda1 = r + t;
095                final double lambda2 = r - t;   
096                final double[] x1, x2;
097                
098                if (a - d > 0) {
099                        x1 = createDoubleVector(s + t, c);
100                        x2 = createDoubleVector(b, -s - t);
101                }
102                else if (a - d < 0) {
103                        x1 = createDoubleVector(b, -s + t);
104                        x2 = createDoubleVector(s - t, c);
105                }
106                else {          // (A - D) == 0
107                        final double bA = Math.abs(b);
108                        final double cA = Math.abs(c);
109                        final double bcS = Math.sqrt(b * c);
110                        if (bA < cA) {                                                  // |b| < |c|
111                                x1 = createDoubleVector(bcS, c);
112                                x2 = createDoubleVector(-bcS, c);
113                        }
114                        else if (bA > cA) {                                     // |b| > |c|
115                                x1 = createDoubleVector(b, bcS);
116                                x2 = createDoubleVector(b, -bcS);
117                        }
118                        else {                          // |B| == |C|
119                                x1 = createDoubleVector(c, c);
120                                x2 = createDoubleVector(-c, c);
121                        }
122                }
123                
124                if (Math.abs(lambda1) >= Math.abs(lambda2)) {   // order eigenvalues by magnitude
125                        eVals[0] = lambda1;
126                        eVals[1] = lambda2;
127                        eVecs[0] = x1;
128                        eVecs[1] = x2;
129                }
130                else {
131                        eVals[0] = lambda2;
132                        eVals[1] = lambda1;
133                        eVecs[0] = x2;
134                        eVecs[1] = x1;
135                }
136                return true;    // real eigenvalues
137        }
138        
139        @Override
140        public boolean isReal() {
141                return isReal;
142        }
143        
144        /**
145         * Returns a vector holding the two real eigenvalues. Both are
146         * {@code NaN} if the associated matrix has no real eigenvalues.
147         * Otherwise the first eigenvalue has greater magnitude than the second.
148         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
149         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
150         * @return a 2-element array of eigenvalues
151         */
152        @Override
153        public double[] getEigenvalues() {
154                return this.eVals;
155        }
156        
157        /**
158         * Returns the k-th eigenvalue (&lambda;_k, k = 0, 1).
159         * {@code NaN} is returned if the the eigenvalue is not real.
160         * 
161         * @param k index (0 or 1)
162         * @return the k-th eigenvalue
163         */
164        @Override
165        public double getEigenvalue(int k) {
166                return eVals[k];
167        }
168        
169        /**
170         * Obsolete, use {@link #getEigenvalue(int)} instead.
171         * @return the first eigenvalue (&lambda;_1)
172         * @deprecated
173         */
174        public double getEigenvalue1() {
175                return eVals[0];
176        }
177        
178        /**
179         * Obsolete, use {@link #getEigenvalue(int)} instead.
180         * @return the second eigenvalue (&lambda;_2)
181         * @deprecated
182         */
183        public double getEigenvalue2() {
184                return eVals[1];
185        }
186        
187        /**
188         * Returns a 2x2 array holding the two real eigenvectors.
189         * When used in the form
190         * <pre>double[][] X = getEigenvalues();</pre>
191         * then {@code X[0]} and {@code X[1]} contain the 1st and 2nd eigenvector,
192         * respectively. If the associated matrix has no real eigenvalues,
193         * then {@code X[0]} and {@code X[1]} are both {@code null}.
194         * Otherwise {@code X[k][0]} and {@code X[k][1]} are the x/y components
195         * of the k-th eigenvector.
196         * The ordering of the returned eigenvectors is the same as for the
197         * eigenvalues returned by {@link #getEigenvalues()}.
198         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
199         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
200         * Obsolete, use {@link #getEigenvector(int)} instead.
201         * @return a 2-element array of 2D eigenvectors
202         * @deprecated
203         */
204        public double[][] getEigenvectors() {
205                return eVecs;
206        }
207        
208        /**
209         * Returns the k-th eigenvector, with k = 0 or 1.
210         * The ordering of the returned eigenvectors is the same as for the
211         * eigenvalues returned by {@link #getEigenvalues()}.
212         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
213         * array and thus results should be used read-only!
214         * @param k index (0 or 1)
215         * @return the k-th eigenvector
216         */
217        @Override
218        public double[] getEigenvector(int k) {
219                return eVecs[k];
220        }
221        
222        @Deprecated
223        public double[] getEigenvector1() {
224                return eVecs[0];
225        }
226        
227        @Deprecated
228        public double[] getEigenvector2() {
229                return eVecs[1];
230        }
231        
232        @Override
233        public String toString() {
234                if (this.isReal) {
235                        return String.format("<%.4f, %.4f, %s, %s>", 
236                                eVals[0], eVals[1], Matrix.toString(eVecs[0]), Matrix.toString(eVecs[1]));
237                }
238                else {
239                        return "<not real>";
240                }
241        }
242                
243}
